<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 170, 290]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 264, 310]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 580, 372]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 781, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 330, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 501, 460]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 487]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 256, 513]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 858, 528]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and 15 minutes on question 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 531, 360, 542]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 767, 557]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 605, 581]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 596]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 854, 836, 863]]<|/det|> This syllabus is approved for use in England, Wales and Northern Ireland as a Cambridge International Level 1/Level 2 Certificate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 876, 735, 888]]<|/det|> This document consists of **10** printed pages and **2** blank pages. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 896, 592, 925]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[820, 916, 904, 927]]<|/det|> [Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 919, 107]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 115, 816, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 337, 340, 355]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 368, 593, 386]]<|/det|>
<pre>A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 400, 146, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 918, 432]]<|/det|>
Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured to the centre of the bob is 50.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 445, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 491, 181, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 491, 584, 508]]<|/det|>
Measure the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 522, 918, 540]]<|/det|>
<form>t = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 554, 181, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 554, 918, 586]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 645, 918, 663]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 677, 181, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 306, 695]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 753, 918, 771]]<|/det|>
<form>T^2 = .................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 785, 181, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 733, 810]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using the equation \(g = \frac{20}{T^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 864, 918, 882]]<|/det|>
<form>g = .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 873, 90]]<|/det|>
Adjust the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured to the centre of the bob is \(100.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 180, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 593, 122]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (a)(i), (a)(ii) and (a)(iii).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 148, 915, 166]]<|/det|>
\[t = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 210, 915, 227]]<|/det|>
\[T = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 270, 915, 288]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 732, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 365, 915, 383]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 619, 121]]<|/det|>

Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 2.2 to show:

• the three resistors connected in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 647, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 572, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 131, 876, 234]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 254, 532, 271]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 284, 146, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 284, 754, 301]]<|/det|>
• Place the screen a distance \(D = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 316, 917, 348]]<|/det|>
• Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the lens is very close to the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 362, 917, 393]]<|/det|>
• Move the lens slowly away from the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 409, 180, 427]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 409, 917, 441]]<|/det|>
• Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 456, 917, 488]]<|/det|>
• Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 502, 180, 520]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 502, 674, 518]]<|/det|>
Calculate the product \(uv\). Record your answer in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of double-walled insulation on the rate of cooling of hot water in a copper container. The student places the copper container inside a larger metal container. He is investigating the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 420, 213]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 314, 243]]<|/det|>
a copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 248, 881, 264]]<|/det|>
a number of metal containers of different diameters (all larger than the copper container)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 269, 281, 283]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 289, 260, 303]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 310, 330, 324]]<|/det|>
a measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 335, 344]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 360, 905, 375]]<|/det|>
<pre>You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 390, 536, 405]]<|/det|>
<pre>You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 421, 324, 436]]<|/det|>
<pre>In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 452, 616, 467]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 483, 530, 498]]<|/det|>
<pre>• state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 514, 918, 545]]<|/det|>
<pre>• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 560, 682, 575]]<|/det|>
<pre>• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 591, 549, 606]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.
